Jean-Dominique Bauby.Action: Manages to open his eyes slowly and follow instructions despite severe paralysis and unconsciousness.
Responds gently and cooperatively to doctor's questions despite confusion and disabilities.
Responds to doctor's questions with effort and understanding despite severe condition, attempts to communicate his name.
Shows vagueness and uncertainty about recent events and surroundings.
Tries hard to communicate by saying his name and his children’s names despite being unable to speak or move, shows persistence and trust in others.
Speaks aloud to himself, attempting to calm himself and express hopefulness and patience in dire circumstances.
Feels despair and isolation when caregivers whisper away from him and seem not to hear him.
Tries hard to speak despite paralysis and inability to move or communicate effectively.
Acknowledges his condition realistically and tries to calm himself with patience and belief in recovery.
Initially struggles to understand and remember what has happened to him.
Uses humor ('I paid a flying visit to New York') to engage with the nurse, showing a light-hearted and friendly demeanor despite his condition.
Observes the nurse's friendly and caring behavior appreciatively but does not respond negatively or dismissively.
Maintains awareness of surroundings, notices details such as the glass frame and his reflection, engages mentally with people entering the room.
Uses humor internally (imagining a flying visit to New York and the frog cartoon) to cope with situation.
Though physically incapacitated and silent, demonstrates cognitive engagement and readiness for visit from neurologist.
Responds with recognition and engagement despite devastating news about his condition.
Shows acceptance and does not display bitterness or anger when learning about locked-in syndrome.
Listens carefully to the doctor's explanation, processes devastating news about his condition, and displays awareness of his situation despite paralysis.
Expresses a moment of despair or disbelief ('Oh Christ, Noirtier de Villefort'), showing emotional response but also cultural and intellectual reference.
Does not show any sign of confusion or misunderstanding about the severity of his condition, indicating mental clarity.
Responds to therapists with humor and light-heartedness ('I'm dead and I've gone to heaven' and 'Just my luck. I've got these two by my bed and I'm helpless.')
Acknowledges and interacts with others despite difficult condition (engages with therapists, communicates via blinking)
Responds with a witty, confident remark to Dr. Lepage's advice to take it easy, showing presence of mind and spirit despite condition.
Mentally likens himself to being trapped inside a diving bell and panics by hammering on the porthole, indicating distress but also active mental engagement.
Internally observes and acknowledges the arrival of therapists and assesses their role and appearance, showing situational awareness.
Lets humor about feeling 'helpless' in front of therapists, indicating acceptance of his situation and no denial.
Responds patiently and cooperatively to therapists' instructions using blinks.
Makes a joke ('Sounds fun -') in response to the physiotherapist's explanation.
Successfully uses eye blinks to communicate clearly and accurately in response to Sandrine's questions, demonstrating understanding and cooperation.
Responds with humor ('Sounds fun -') despite his condition, showing mental agility and emotional resilience.
Reflects on his past life positively, saying 'And, God, what a great life it was.'
Responds accurately through blinks to complex questions indicating presence of mind despite physical limitations.
Reflects on his prior role as editor-in-chief of Elle magazine with confidence, implying professional skill and leadership.
Engages mentally with the world around him, recalling past experiences clearly despite his condition.
Physically unable to communicate except through blinks, but uses this method skillfully and deliberately.
Does not verbally respond to the ophthalmologist’s patronizing tone and dismissive attitude, showing no overt confrontation or resistance.
Expresses fear and distrust toward Dr. Mercier, showing vulnerability and a critical but human response to perceived arrogance and insensitivity.
Responds to medical staff with resigned but polite blinking, recognizing their presence without hostility.
Does not retaliate aggressively despite feeling threatened and misunderstood by the doctor.
Expresses terror and distrust toward the doctor, showing fear and vulnerability during the eye surgery.
Manages to communicate clearly and calmly through blinks despite distress, indicating controlled responses in difficult circumstances.
Resigns to the procedure without resistance after expressing initial fear, demonstrating acceptance rather than active control.
Makes self-deprecating humorous comments about his clothing and situation, sharing the moment with others present.
Engages with medical staff playfully and tolerantly despite his difficult condition.
Manages to sit in and handle the wheelchair during his first trial despite severe physical limitations.
Demonstrates ironic, emotionally aware commentary about his condition and clothing, showing mental sharpness.
No visible signs of panic or defeat in response to being lifted and placed in the wheelchair; remains composed.
Expresses horror and rejection upon seeing his mutilated reflection, wishes to communicate distress but cannot.
Demonstrates self-awareness and vulnerability about his changed appearance.
Notices and reflects on his physical appearance with shock and distress, expressing a wish to communicate but unable to do so.
Maintains awareness and observation of his surroundings, despite his physical limitations.
Speaks gently to Sylvie, expressing longing to hear her voice and encouraging her to talk to him
Admits awareness of his changed appearance sensitively, showing vulnerability
Clarifies Sylvie is mother of his children, not his wife, maintaining honesty and clarity
Understands complex communication setup using blinks to answer yes/no questions, showing cognitive clarity.
Expresses self-awareness about his changed appearance and condition but maintains engagement and desire for communication.
Does not initiate communication beyond blinking answers; mainly listens passively during the visit.
Acknowledges friends’ withdrawal but takes blame himself saying 'it was all my fault, I’m a bastard'
Expresses appreciation for the speech therapist Sandrine, saying he likes her and hopes she can help
Shows openness and desire for friendship with Sylvie, pleased they stayed friends
Admits to being plunged into despair, showing emotional vulnerability especially in response to Sylvie’s care
Does not express anger or resentment towards those who 'deserted' him, instead accepts situation calmly
Responds to being cared for like a newborn with humor and laughter despite his condition.
Acknowledges the difficult loss of relationship and inability to make amends, expressing sorrow.
Maintains a sense of humor and self-awareness despite his severe physical condition.
Responds passively to nurses' care and attempts to communicate but physical incapacity limits active responses.
Responds affirmatively to Béatrice's playful encouragement to blow a kiss
Expresses frustration gently when told to practice tongue exercises ('This just isn’t fair')
Participates in difficult rehabilitation exercises despite apparent difficulty and frustration
Openly acknowledges shared sorrow with Béatrice ('Believe me, so am I')
Responds affirmatively by blinking when prompted to blow a kiss, showing willingness to engage in therapy exercises despite severe physical limitations.
Attempts to move his tongue slightly as encouraged by Beatrice, demonstrating effort and partial control over his impaired muscles.
Expresses frustration by internal voice saying 'This just isn't fair,' reflecting awareness but also emotional struggle.
Fails to feel the massage touch on his face despite Beatrice's attempts, indicating current physical insensitivity but no indication of giving up.
Suddenly aggressive, telling Beatrice to stop praying and not to waste time.
Responds patiently with a blink to Sandrine's explanation of the communication system, cooperating with her help.
Patiently tries to communicate using the difficult blinking method despite frustration
Acknowledges old friend Pierre Roussin warmly and recognizes him immediately
Successfully participates in learning to communicate with blinks despite difficulty and frustration.
Expresses doubt and pessimism about the method, saying 'This is a nightmare, It'll never work.'
Gives up his seat on a flight to Hong Kong to Roussin, demonstrating kindness and generosity.
Welcomes Roussin and allows him to stay despite awkwardness, showing tolerance and friendliness.
Does not interrupt or dismiss Roussin's difficult story, indicating sincerity and empathy through attentive presence.
Communicates effectively by blinking to convey yes or no responses despite severe physical limitations.
Allows others to take an active role in conversation, such as Sandrine explaining his blinking system and Roussin speaking at length.
Does not interrupt or correct Roussin’s narrative, even when it seems awkward or potentially inaccurate (e.g., Roussin referring to being a hostage).
Feels ashamed for not calling Roussin after his return from Beirut, showing guilt and self-awareness.
Expresses internal struggle and recognition of his own prisoner state compared to Roussin's freedom, reflecting sincere self-reflection.
Expresses a desire to die despite others' care and love; internally conflicted but sincere about his feelings.
Attempts to communicate complex thoughts by blinking out words despite extreme physical limitations.
Expresses a wish to die, indicating a moment of emotional vulnerability and despair.
Withdraws from communication, saying he will not say another word or even blink, indicating resignation.
Mentally reflects clearly and purposefully despite physical paralysis, showing strong internal cognitive competence.
Allows Laurent to try communicating using the alphabet card without showing frustration; remains silent but tolerant during the awkward interaction.
Does not respond or engage actively when Laurent tries to initiate conversation; remains withdrawn and silent.
Does not respond or engage actively when Laurent attempts to communicate using the alphabet card system.
Maintains composure and quietude despite awkward, failed attempts at communication; internally reflects on the situation with insight and dark humor.
Outraged and defensive when hearing he is called a 'vegetable', humorously questions what sort of vegetable he is
Dismisses the ignorant opinion of the Café crowd, defends his mental acuity, shows protective attitude toward himself
Directs Laurent to leave to avoid tiring him despite his own apparent desire for company
Sarcastically insults the unnamed person in the café
Shows clear, sharp mind and wit by rejecting the label 'vegetable' and arguing mentally against it with humor and indignation.
Swivels his eye to maintain visual contact and awareness despite physical limitations.
Engages in verbal repartee even when physically constrained, demonstrating cognitive alertness.
Does not physically follow Laurent but remains mentally engaged, showing adaptation to his condition.
Sarcastically comments on Laurent's crash-helmet before he leaves.
Reflects on his life with a tone of melancholy and regret, acknowledging missed opportunities and lost chances.
Responds patiently to Sandrine's firm but caring instruction, blinks to communicate affirmatively, participates cooperatively in the painstaking communication exercise.
Remains silent but engaged during the difficult interaction, showing trust in Sandrine's stern but supportive approach.
Engages cooperatively in the challenging communication task with Sandrine, signaling readiness and successfully indicating 'Thank you' through blinks.
Shares his imaginative and memory-based escape from paralysis with Sandrine, expressing vulnerability and a private joke about his condition.
Describes vivid, affectionate fantasies involving loved ones and beautiful places, showing emotional openness and tenderness.
Smiles with exhilaration skiing, recalling himself as handsome and glamorous, laughs joyously.
Allows Sandrine to patiently communicate by blinking letters in a slow but fluent exchange.
Uses blinking method to communicate fluently and effectively with Sandrine, engaging in letter-by-letter conversation despite physical limitations.
Remembers and mentally revisits his past self confidently, showing self-awareness and mental agility.
Makes a rule to never feel sorry for himself again.
Finds a reason for his condition and involves Sandrine by asking for a favour.
Makes a personal rule to never feel sorry for himself again, displaying mental resolve.
Clearly communicates with Sandrine using the blinking letter code to express complex thoughts and requests.
Finds a reason for his condition and consciously shares it to give purpose.
Wants to fulfill his contract by writing a book despite his severe condition
Organizes a disciplined routine for writing despite severe physical limitation, showing planning and clear communication skills.
Expresses gratitude and confidence in his assistant Claude, demonstrating trust and professional collaboration.
Mentions physical discomfort and feelings of imprisonment but persists in work, showing resilience and mental perseverance.
Reflects on the history of the hospital with a poetic and appreciative tone, showing sensitivity and a gentle humor about patients' condition.
Accepts his state and refers to fellow patients as 'a battalion of cripples' with a frank but compassionate perspective, indicating tolerance and sincerity.
Enjoys small pleasures like the terrace and the view of suburbs with imaginative appreciation, conveying friendliness toward the world despite limitations.
Places himself under the protection of the lighthouse, describing it as a brotherly and reassuring symbol for the sick.
Reflects warmly on watching the sunset and the lighthouse beam, suggesting peaceful acceptance and appreciation.
Mentions ‘I’ve got gay locked in syndrome, and I am nuts about your friend’ with a wink.
Calmly observes and reflects on the lighthouse as a symbol of protection and reassurance, showing thoughtful insight despite his condition.
Remains mentally active and engaged while alone after Claude leaves, indicating mental resilience and sustained cognitive engagement.
Communicates via blinking and winking to respond to the workers, showing adaptive use of limited physical means to interact effectively.
Fails to immediately clarify or reject the mistaken identity and comments from the workers, suggesting some possible missed opportunity to assert himself.
Responds to Sandrine’s respectful treatment and smiles when communicating by blinking, showing engagement and appreciation.
Laughs along with others despite being the subject of jokes and misunderstanding.
Does not directly confront or correct Telecom workers’ dismissive tone about his condition.
Closes his eyes after the interaction, indicating possible resignation or reflection rather than hostility.
Communicates using blinks to spell out words, demonstrating patience and mental acuity despite physical limitations.
Engages with visitors and remains mentally present and aware, even when others doubt his cognitive abilities.
Remains silent and does not correct misconceptions or assert himself vocally, relying solely on eye blinks for communication.
Acknowledges and appreciates those praying for him from various cultures and religions, including his daughter and Béatrice.
Accepts Béatrice's suggestion to attend Mass despite not being religious, showing tolerance and openness.
Admits trying to organize spiritual support using diverse religious practices and acknowledges possible hypocrisy, showing sincerity and humility.
Attempts to explain his lack of religiosity calmly and honestly to Béatrice despite her differing view.
Acknowledges and organizes diverse spiritual efforts worldwide supporting him, showing openness and pragmatic strategy.
Expresses self-awareness in admitting a degree of hypocrisy in trying anything for survival, showing reflective intelligence.
Passively accepts Béatrice's insistence on attending Mass though not personally motivated; does not resist or take control over the situation.
Watches Béatrice crossing herself devoutly in prayer, appears receptive to spiritual presence.
Engages with Father Lucien with some humor ('A-ha! The hidden agenda.'), shows warmth and a friendly attitude despite his condition.
Does not respond to Father Lucien’s offers of Communion or blessing, remains silent.
Observes others attentively, participates by blinking to communicate with great patience and precision during the alphabet communication process.
Fails to respond verbally or initiate communication beyond blinking, seeming passive or withdrawn in a moment requiring active engagement (Holy Communion and blessings discussion).
Expresses empathy and sorrow for the monks who were killed, acknowledging their suffering.
Politely declines the pilgrimage invitation from Father Lucien, indicating awareness of his own preferences but without rudeness.
Engages in playful banter with Josephine during their drive, showing a familiar and friendly dynamic.
Responds thoughtfully to Father Lucien’s suggestion about the pilgrimage, recalling he has already been to Lourdes and implicitly making a considered decision not to join.
Engages in a witty and quick verbal exchange with Josephine during a fast car ride, demonstrating mental alertness and the ability to keep pace with social interactions.

Does not react to Father Lucien’s uncertain response about the monks killed by extremists beyond noting his ear pain, reflecting some possible limitation in confronting or processing distressing or complex religious-political matters.
Smiles at a paraplegic who sticks his tongue out, then turns away embarrassed.
Refuses to participate in the Madonna pilgrimage, expresses skepticism and concern for others.
Responds sarcastically to Josephine's insults and leaves her struggling through the wheelchairs alone.
Jokes with Joséphine about her taste in souvenirs.
Reluctantly buys the Madonna souvenir as a present despite his lack of enthusiasm.
Expresses discomfort making love with the Madonna statue watching, sharing his feelings openly.
Decides to split up with Joséphine, acknowledges difficult realities without bitterness.
Turns off the lights but spares the Madonna’s light for Joséphine’s comfort.
Walks alone among groups of pilgrims and youth, appears introspective and solitary.
Decides to end his relationship with Josephine thoughtfully and with explanation, showing awareness of circumstances.
Obeys Josephine’s request carefully, turning off lights but leaving the Madonna illuminated, showing attentiveness.
Walks alone through Lourdes, taking in surroundings thoughtfully.
Stops and contemplates the Madonna in the shop window, suggesting reflection but no concrete action.
Participates in rehab exercises with encouragement from therapists, attempts to learn speech sounds despite difficulties.
Insists on reading the passage himself rather than having it read to him, demonstrating a desire for sincere personal engagement.
Struggles with speech exercises patiently, responding positively to encouragement from others.
Focuses on nostalgic family photographs, showing a connection to personal and familial history.
Manages to articulate and practice difficult sounds (e.g., 'La-la-la') despite physical struggles.
Insists on reading the typescript himself rather than having it read to him, showing confidence in his intellectual abilities.
Continues personal grooming by mixing shaving lather despite physical limitations, showing maintenance of personal care and autonomy.
Wraps his elderly father in a towel and shaves him carefully despite the father's misgivings.
Engages in light teasing banter with his father about his mother, showing humor and affection.
Responds to his father's comments with some sarcasm and rudeness (e.g., 'You mean she feeds you every four hours?').
Shows patience by answering his father's repeated questions and listening to him.
Dismisses mother's concerns about tiring his father with a light challenge ('How can a shave tire you?').
Carefully wraps his elderly father in a warm towel before shaving him, showing thoughtfulness and attention to detail.
Applies shaving lather skillfully using a brush, followed by massaging it in with his fingers, demonstrating deftness and familiarity with the task.
Engages in light, witty banter with his father, indicating social intelligence and confidence.
Explains his creative project of re-writing The Count of Monte Cristo in modern times with a female lead, illustrating intellectual ambition and clarity of thought.
Responds to concerns about tiring his father by slightly dismissing the caution with charm, showing confidence but possibly overlooking physical limits.
Teases Papinou lightly during the shave, creating a playful, familiar atmosphere.
Promises Papinou a great party to celebrate his good prognosis, showing care and optimism.
Keeps Papinou's confidence about missing Jean-Do's mother a secret, demonstrating trustworthiness.
Avoids engaging deeply with Papinou on sensitive family matters, showing some reluctance or emotional restraint.
Skillfully shaves Papinou despite difficulties, maintaining control and humor.
Responds with dry humor and confidence when threatened with a lawsuit for shaving Papinou.
Engages in meaningful conversation, demonstrating awareness and social intelligence despite physical limitations.
Avoids discussing emotionally painful topics (relationship with Sylvie, children) when prompted.
Jokes gently with Papinou about cologne and helps him with shaving and looking in the mirror.
Listens patiently and attentively as Papinou struggles to express himself and shows emotional vulnerability.
Remains still and silent when his father expresses pride, reflecting deep feeling and respect.
Thanks Sandrine for swatting the fly from his nose.
Observes others in the rehab center with interest and awareness.
Remembers a detail that others have forgotten, indicating mental alertness despite physical limitations.
Engages in precise eye movements to communicate letters and words, showing skill and patience in a difficult situation.
Responds to encouragement from Sandrine and Béatrice by moving his tongue and grunting affirmatively, showing engagement and cooperation.
Mentions Dr. Lepage said good morning only once, expressing delight and humor.
No negative or cold reaction to the medical staff or nurses; appears accepting and trusting of their care.
Successfully moves his tongue on command when prompted by caregivers.
Communicates by blinking to spell out words clearly with the help of a partner.
Turned his head slowly from side to side as a deliberate action despite physical limitations.
Grunts ambiguously when asked a question instead of providing clear confirmation.
Invites Claude to join him and shares an oyster with her.
Expresses impatience and longing regarding his feeding tube and inability to eat normally.
Examines the label of the wine and nods approval.
Charmingly invites Claude to share his oyster and successfully engages her.
Expresses frustration about his feeding tube and inability to eat normally.
Watches the waiter expertly fillet the fish and shares the meal attentively with Claude, ensuring he also enjoys the food.
Smiles admiringly at the sommelier’s wine service and toasts with Claude.
Examines the wine label carefully and nods approval before tasting.
Watches the fish being expertly filleted before eating, then eats elegantly and delicately.
Sprinkles salt and squeezes lemon with child-like anticipation but still eats with elegance and refinement.
Makes the first cut in the steak, demonstrating confidence and skill, then eats hungrily and cleans the plate carefully.
Points precisely to five cheeses from the selection, showing decisiveness and knowledge.
Laughs and shares a joyful moment with Claude over coffee and cognac.
Observes silently while Sylvie and children appear hesitant but still come close, suggesting his openness despite his condition.
Laughs and enjoys a moment of bliss with Claude despite difficult circumstances.
Responds slowly to surroundings (e.g., slowly swivels head) and appears physically limited due to condition.
Responds to children’s Father’s Day gestures with quiet appreciation and gentle affection, acknowledges his role as a father despite his condition.
Allows children and Sylvie to care for him without complaint, accepting their support and closeness.
Does not verbally express emotions extensively, often solitary in thought and observation, which may appear reserved.
Maintains emotional composure and appreciates the moment with his children despite severe physical limitations, demonstrating emotional intelligence and presence.
Interacts gently with children, acknowledges imperfections ('tiny fragment of a dad is still a dad'), showing insight and acceptance.
Passively accepts physical condition and drooling without visible embarrassment or frustration, showing a calm acceptance rather than active coping or control.
Shakes his head playfully to 'show off' when Sylvie mentions he can move his head.
Engages patiently and cooperatively in the slow, difficult communication process with Sylvie using blinks to answer her questions.
Responds with short, minimal answers indicating some emotional reservation or fatigue during visitor discussion.
Successfully communicates by blinking to select letters using the alphabet method despite severe physical limitations.
Demonstrates patience and composure during communication sessions with Sylvie, showing mental resilience and focus.
Responds with minimal, slow communication (only a few blinks) which could suggest limited expressiveness or difficulty in conveying complex thoughts.
Engages in light self-deprecating humor calling himself a 'zombie for a father,' sharing the moment with Sylvie and the children.
Responds to Sylvie's concern with minimal but reassuring blinks, showing subtle attentiveness to others' worries.
Absence of explicit expressions of frustration or negativity despite difficult circumstances.
Maintains a sense of humor and emotional connection, making others laugh despite his severe condition.
Shows awareness of the situation and his relationships, despite his physical limitations.
Experiences symptoms such as a hoarse rattle, appears physically vulnerable, and does not communicate distress effectively.
Feels deep grief over his inability to physically express affection to his children, showing emotional openness and sincere vulnerability.
Declines to play Hangman with Theophile citing his physical limitations, but appreciates the child's company and effort.
Suppresses tears and manages emotional grief silently, showing emotional control.
Responds to Theophile's invitation to play Hangman with a humorous internal remark acknowledging his own limitations.
Engages in a cognitive game (Hangman) despite severe physical limitations, demonstrating mental agility and adaptive communication.
Allows Sylvie to hold his inert hand tightly, shares a quiet moment of mutual vulnerability as she cries silently.
Remains silent and observant while children play and interact around him, showing patience and acceptance.
Does not react negatively to Théophile’s teasing or impolite comments about his inability to sing.
Observes the tide receding and watches bathers leaving the beach, showing awareness of his surroundings despite physical limitations.
Remains silent and passive while others speak and act around him, unable to actively participate in conversations or actions.
Allows and welcomes Theophile to hold his hand tightly, showing receptiveness to affection.
Responds positively and appreciatively to Sylvie and Celeste's efforts to comfort him with the fish drawing and affectionate gestures despite his physical limitations.
Engages silently and gratefully in goodbyes, showing sincere connection with visitors.
No sign of hostility or withdrawal despite his immobilized state, demonstrating tolerance and good-natured acceptance.
Admits to feeling sorry for himself but openly discusses it with Claude.
Compliments Claude sincerely, recognizing her patience and caring nature.
Expresses interest in learning more about Claude’s life, showing curiosity and openness.
Acknowledges Claude’s lack of ego as a miracle, demonstrating appreciation and respect.
Reluctance to accept compliments immediately ('Stop it, I don’t like compliments.'), showing modesty rather than warmth or coldness.
Engages in meaningful dialogue despite severe physical limitations, uses blinking communication effectively to interact and direct conversation.
Expresses self-pity but quickly acknowledges and reframes it, showing emotional self-awareness and control.
Demonstrates curiosity and interest in others by asking questions about Claude’s life, indicating intellectual engagement.
Shows some hesitation and reliance on others for memory and information retrieval (e.g., 'Ask someone'), indicating limitations in independent recall.
Allows Claude to take the lead in caretaking tasks and conversation, showing perhaps some passivity or acceptance of roles but not necessarily lack of competence.
Chooses not to ask Théophile about a frightening memory to avoid causing more fear.
Prefers to remember an important detail himself rather than having Claude find out.
Acknowledges presence of children visiting him by Claude, showing awareness of others' feelings.
Struggles to hold back tears during phone conversation with Papinou.
Does not directly respond verbally, relies on Claude to answer during difficult emotional exchange.
Communicates and responds through Claude during difficult conversation, showing emotional restraint despite tears.
Relies on others (Claude) to convey his thoughts since he is physically incapacitated.
Shows understanding and patience during the fragmented, difficult phone conversation with Papinou.
Acknowledges the emotional pain of his father, recognizing the difficulty for him to speak to a son who cannot reply.
Expresses uncertainty and emotional struggle when asked if he is there, showing vulnerability and openness.
Effectively uses eye blinks to communicate difficult words and phrases, showing patience and mental agility despite severe physical limitations.
Internally reflects on the emotional difficulty of his father's attempts to communicate, showing insight and emotional intelligence.
Exhibits moments of uncertainty and self-doubt in communication ('At times I don’t know anymore').
Remains physically passive and reliant on others, observed silently gazing at his reflection and surroundings without outward attempts to interact.
Laughs despite his tragic condition, shares a moment of joy with Empress Eugenie who joins in and encourages him
Acknowledges his physical deformity and misery with self-deprecating humor and nervous laughter
Responds with curiosity and friendliness to the female nurse’s smile and giggle in the corridor
Receives and appreciates a birthday celebration by patients, nurses, and visitors, showing connection and warmth
Participates actively and patiently in speech therapy exercises with encouragement and shared laughter among patients.
Participates actively and correctly in a difficult speech exercise despite severe physical limitations.
Receives encouragement from others and remains focused on practicing precise speech sounds.
Shows no signs of giving up or frustration during the challenging articulation task.
Smiles in response to the birthday celebration and surprises, expresses gratitude for the outing and company.
Quietly receives surprises and kindness from others without complaint or bitterness.
Successfully communicates using blinking to indicate letters, demonstrated by Sandrine's recognition and others' applause.
Smiles subtly despite severe physical limitations, showing emotional control and awareness.
Expresses gratitude intelligently and appreciatively during the boat outing.
Thanks Claude sincerely for reading to him.
Engages in light, self-deprecating humor comparing himself to a sinister literary character.
Invites Claude to discuss the coincidence and his condition openly, showing trust and openness.
Persistently comments on the eerie nature of his situation, which could create discomfort but is shared with a close person.
Recites a passage from memory verbatim, demonstrating remarkable mental acuity despite physical limitations.
Makes insightful literary connections between his own condition and the character Monsieur Noirtier, showing intelligence and reflective ability.
Engages with Claude in a confident and witty manner, asserting himself despite his condition.
Engages in warm, imaginative conversation with Claude, sharing poetic thoughts and metaphors about their situation.
Shows gentle humor and self-deprecation about his writing efforts and fate.
Responds attentively and politely to the fisherman calling Mademoiselle Claude.
Reflects on the consequences of rewriting Dumas and acknowledges it as a lesson, showing self-awareness about his creative decisions.
Engages imaginatively with Claude in a poetic and thoughtful manner, demonstrating mental agility despite physical limitations.
Plans to write another book after finishing the current one, indicating goal-setting and confidence in future achievements.
Does not respond directly to the fisherman’s call, requiring Sylvie to manage the practical task of handling letters, possibly showing some delegation or omission in handling his environment.
Allows Sylvie to facilitate communication despite tense atmosphere, attempts to express himself through blinks despite difficulty
Does not interrupt or confront the woman’s difficult emotional admission, listens silently
No explicit response or rejection to the woman’s self-admitted cowardice and emotional pain, indicating tolerance and understanding
Communicates using a complex system of blinks (E-T-A-O...), showing mental acuity and deliberate control despite physical limitations.
Listens attentively to personal, emotionally difficult conversations and processes them silently without apparent confusion or loss of composure.
Does not interrupt or overtly react to the woman's difficult confession, suggesting patience and emotional steadiness rather than impulsiveness or lack of control.
Expresses regret about refusing to have a child with Sylvie, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Indicates love for Sylvie but is hesitant to say it directly in front of her, showing private affection and respect.
Acknowledges having had exceptional women in his life with a tone of gratitude.
Offers his seat on the plane to Roussin, demonstrating selflessness and consideration.
Pulls the lever marked 'PULL ME' despite uncertainty of outcome, engaging actively with his environment.
Corrects Roussin about his destination from Hong-Kong to Beirut confidently while metaphorically standing up for him.
Navigates mentally among wax models of people around the bed, examining them closely and interpreting their expressions.
Attempts to communicate with the nurse by blinking to express choices.
Reflects on his dreams and emotions thoughtfully despite his condition.
Sings softly with nurses and fellow patients to lift his spirits during rehab.
Feels and admits fear and a sense of doom openly.
Twitches a smile in response to Beatrice's comment about the beautiful song.
Reflects on his situation with a poetic and gentle tone, likening his heartbeats to butterfly wings and showing humor about 'butterfly hearing.'
Mentions eagerness to see the future despite his condition, showing a positive and open attitude.
Mentions he has a visitor and intends to 'show off' like Céleste, sharing his situation with others.
Mentally observes his condition with poetic insight and humor despite severe disability.
Acknowledges his physical limitations but maintains a forward-looking mindset and a degree of self-awareness.
Describes himself as an 'indomitable vegetable' showing self-deprecating humor and awareness of his state.
Attempts to sing a song for friends despite physical difficulty and frustration.
Refuses to sing on initial requests (grunts 'Uh-uh').
Communicates with friends acknowledging their presence and affection ('I said okay').
Communicates intentionally through grunts and limited vocalization despite severe physical limitations.
Attempts to sing a song, demonstrating effort to engage and connect with others.
Makes a choking sound and shakes his head when distressed, effectively signaling a problem.
Unable to continue singing and experiences distress, indicating vulnerability in physical capability.
Looks through the ambulance window at familiar scenes and people despite physical limitation, showing engagement with his environment.
Recognizes a couple he knows but cannot recall their names, indicating a sincere human connection despite memory loss.
Greets Paul, the doorman, with a friendly ‘Morning, Paul.’
Focuses his attention admiringly on his new car, showing some self-involvement or material appreciation without evident warmth.
Hugs Celeste and Theophile tightly when they run into his arms, plans theatre and dinner outing with children, offers oysters generously.
Waves half-heartedly to Sylvie and greets her awkwardly.
Carefully admires and operates a new BMW with evident pleasure and control, smoothly driving through city and country roads while engaging warmly with his children.
Shows concern by instructing Théophile to run and get Aunt Diane urgently despite his own distress.
Maintains composure enough to give clear instructions during physical distress.
Recognizes he is unwell and insists to stop and get help promptly.
Attempts to maintain control over the car and his breathing despite feeling ill.
Keeps calm enough to direct Théophile to get Aunt Diane for assistance.
Remains conscious and responsive during extreme physical distress, enabling communication through blinking despite paralysis.
Lying in sterile, impersonal hospital environment with no personal effects around.
Despite severe physical paralysis and hyperventilating during a medical emergency, he remains lucid enough to participate in a complex communication system by blinking to form letters.
Does not physically respond or attempt to control the emergency situation due to paralysis.
Successfully uses a blink-based communication system to spell out words and read the book's dedication, showing intellectual engagement despite physical limitations.
Chooses not to hear the reviews of his book, indicating a controlled, deliberate emotional and cognitive boundary, reflecting self-awareness and confidence.
